sentence: Wall Street's averages were mixed at midday on Thursday as investors comb through mixed quarterly results, the fallout from an extended government shutdown, and heightened tensions between the US and China after the US government opened an investigation into Huawei for stealing trade secrets.
Weighed down by Home Depot ( HD ), the Dow Jones Industrial Average was still struggling to catch up to the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, both of which were holding modest gains.

Stocks were off to an uneasy start after Morgan Stanley's ( MS ) disappointing results compounded the existing negative tone that followed Wednesday's news of the Department of Justice's probe into China's Huawei.

Although the People's Bank of China continued to pump massive amounts of liquidity into the banking system ($168.7 billion so far this week), fears that a Huawei probe will further erode US/China relations weighed on overseas markets.
Sentiment improved on reassurances from Morgan Stanley's CEO that soft Q4 results were an aberration, and bullish US economic data.
First time unemployment claims were down 3,000 for the week ending Jan 12 to 213,000, beating expectations for an increase of 5,000 to 221,000.
Also, business conditions in the mid-Atlantic region improved measurably in January as the Philadelphia Fed index jumped to 17.0 from 9.1 in December, well above estimates for an increase to 10.0.

Weighed down by earnings-related pressure on the banking sector and worries about US tariffs on imported autos, Europe's major market averages all closed lower with auto and leisure stocks underperforming.

Shares of Germany's Daimler, Volkswagen and BMW and France's Peugeot and Renault were losing ground after US Senator Chuck Grassley said President Donald Trump was inclined to impose tariffs on European autos in order to win concessions for US agriculture exports.
Additionally, France's Societe Generale warned that its trading revenue could be down as much as 20% due to a "challenging" market.
This set the stock price back nearly 6% and left France's CAC-40 one of the biggest laggards among EU indices.
Crude oil was down $0.35 to $51.96 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $0.08 to $3.45 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was down $2.70 to $1,291.10 an ounce, while silver was down $0.11 to $15.52 an ounce.
Copper was up $0.008 to $2.68 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 1.0% to $10.95 with the United States Natural Gas Fund up 1.59% to $28.67.
Among precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was up 0.28% to 20.70 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.15% to $122.08.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.48% to $14.56.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

NYSE Composite Index was up 28.84 points (+0.24%) to 11,936.45

Dow Jones Industrial Index was down 34.87 points (-0.16%) to 24,171.40

S&P 500 was up 6.25 points (+0.24%) to 2,622.35

Nasdaq Composite Index was up 17.02 points (+0.24%) to 7,051.71

FTSE 100 was down 27.76 points (-0.40%) to 6834.92

DAX was down 12.62 points (-0.12%) to 10,918.62

CAC 40 was down 16.37 points (-0.34%) to 4,794.37

Nikkei 225 was down 40.48 points (-0.20%) to 20,402.27

Hang Seng Index was down 146.47 points (-0.54%) to 26,755.63

Shanghai China Composite Index was down 10.79 points (-0.42%) to 2,559.64

NYSE Energy Sector Index was down 0.05 points (0.00%) to 10,088.70

NYSE Financial Sector Index was down 5.03 points (-0.07%) to 7,422.37

NYSE Healthcare Sector Index was up 77.78 points (+0.52%) to 15,346.06
